title: Hey, look at me! I'm totally entangled I with not-me!
year_place:
Beiqiu Museum of Contemporary Art,
Nanjing, China
descriptionENG:
Beiqiu Museum of Contemporary Art (BMCA) is honored to present Mexican artist Gabriel Rico's first solo exhibition in China, I'M TOTALLY ENTANGLED WITH NOT-ME! The exhibition features 37 works of the artist in recent years, including many new and unexhibited ones. The exhibition will run from August 13 to November 13, 2022.

Gabriel Rico is regarded as one of the most talented artists of contemporary Latin America. Born in Lagos de Moreno, Mexico in 1980, he currently resides and works in Guadalajara, Mexico. His sculptures and installations have been shown in a number of international exhibitions, and in 2019, he participated in the 58th Venice Biennale. Being an architect by training, Rico has a strong affinity for natural elements and specializes in incorporating them in his creations. Through a combination of readymade and man-made objects, Rico explores themes ranging from intangible forms of sound spectrum to the production and consumption of everyday food, provoking us to think about our own culture through the asymmetry of things. He pays homage to the post-surrealist and poverty art movements through his use of neon, taxidermy, ceramics, stone, tree branches, and personal belongings. In this exhibition, Gabriel Rico combines the creation of natural and non-natural objects, inviting the viewer to reflect on the juxtaposition of these elements of human civilization in a poetic and humorous way.

The theme of this exhibition, I'M TOTALLY ENTANGLED WITH NOT-ME! , is derived from the quantum entanglement effect in physics. Despite being in Mexico, the artist's work and his way of thinking about the world are presented in parallel in the art museum in China. The arrows and mathematical symbols in the artworks make visual comparisons between different objects, suggesting an internal logic and provoking thought. The selection of these works and the design of the exhibition are inspired by Mayan myth as told in the Popol Vuh, illustrating the connection between technology and art with human knowledge through the myth of the ''Twin Gods'' of Mexican culture and Mayan civilization. Hunahpú and Ixbalanqué, the Twin Gods in the myth, had a legendary origin. They bothered the Lords of Xibalbá when playing at the court of the Mayan Ball Game their father had built and were called to visit the Underworld. They went through several trials and defeated the Ajawab of Xibalbá. After their victory in the Underworld, Hunahpú became the Sun and Ixbalanqué became the Moon.

The artist's decision to stage his first solo exhibition in China at the Beiqiu Museum of Contemporary Art is significant. Located in Huangya Catherine Plaza in Xuanwu District, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, the museum is backed by Jilong Mountain and is a unique art museum set on a hill in the heart of the city. The BMCA features a collection, exhibition, research and development, and education of contemporary art. The art museum has been restored and reinforced over the years, and the interior of the concrete-poured pavilion presents a collision of industrial and primitive. History, nature, and reality intertwined, pioneers and traditions constantly tested, the localization, multimodality, and unpredictability of contemporary art are all addressed here. Located on the uppermost level of the last century's bunker, the art museum retains the original architectural structure from more than twenty years ago. The exhibition space has the sense of a cave or subterranean, comparable to the space where the Twin Gods defeated the Ajawab in Mayan mythology's Underworld. Both Mexico and China are ancient civilizations. Southeastern Mexico and Nanjing are geographically apart, but they share a rich history, culture, and art. The implication of the works and the location of the exhibition give rise to a coherence between time and place.

The myth of the Twin Gods is related to the two branches of human knowledge with which the total of the pieces presented in this exhibition are linked: Art and Science. These works are seemingly unconnected objects, full of symbols, random relationships, geometry, and chaos. Appreciating them is like reading a book in the dark. Reflections on art and science allow the viewers to break free from the tedious routine and connect the self with reality in a playful way, which is exactly what the theme of the exhibition is trying to convey.

Cynthia Gutiérrez, a close friend of Gabriel Rico and fellow outstanding Mexican contemporary artist, has written a beautiful text for this exhibition. Her poetic language leads the viewers into the world of Gabriel Rico's art.

In the emptiness of the desert emerge cactus with golden pitayas and pencas made of ground and stuffed viscera. Thirst for gold. In the sky, a square sun. The loop is broken. History stops repeating itself. The wheel of nature does not turn. Spears of light piercing and illuminating the totem of the end of time. Consumed idols carrying dead nature in a sea of sand.Dazed and sad bird, giddy hare. Animals persist, but only as trophies. They look at us, still. They pose on worlds simulated by colored balls, elevated by golden rays emerging from rocks surrounded by rings of light. Holograms. Appearance. Death that looks at you. Illusory uprising. Artificial return. False landscapes do not deceive me. Let the birds fly in the dissected world! Has everything died? The shadow of the world is a plane. I walk it painting ghosts.

Paths, paths, trajectories. The tireless search for knowledge. The absurd explanation of an inexplicable world. Ink that suffocates songs, that clouds the senses, that numbs our being. My head is a book. Silence, unbearable weight, monument to permanence, to immobility. My head is a stone.

The exhibition is organized by the Beiqiu Museum of Contemporary Art, with sponsorship from the Huanya Art Foundation and Galerie Perrotin. The exhibition is located at the Banshan Garden at the back of Huanya Catherine Plaza.

title: An animal i am!
year_place: Shenzhen Sea World Culture and Arts Center, Shenzhen, Nanshan, China
dataESP:
Exposición individual

Curaduría por Qiu Zhijie
descriptionENG:
The title of Gabriel Rico’s solo exhibition at Sea World Culture and Arts Center—“An Animal I Am!”—is simple, but slippery. “I am an animal,” the artist says, echoing the call of the wild; “an animal I am!,” he howls, unleashing an even deeper, more personal awakening.

How should we interpret the animals that populate the Mexican artist’s work, in the form of actual taxidermy or sculptural forms? They’re certainly more than just mute beasts of the field or forest. In sandplay therapy—a type of therapeutic “play” whose invention arguably dates to the 1920s—animal figures are significant and potent symbols. Animals also have a central role in other spiritual corners, from tribal totems to shamanic traditions.

Jungian psychology focuses on awakening the archetypes that exist in the depths of the collective human subconscious. In this modality, animals are the indispensable communicators of the entire life cycle, cultural heroes who stole fire and seeds from God. They are prophets, the keepers of secrets, both the sacrificial offering and the one who sacrifices.

Of course, the bestial thread in contemporary art runs deep. Consider the epic sculptural work of the late Huang Yongping, which incorporated enormous animal forms—elephants, octopi—using both organic and man-made materials.

Joseph Beuys, whose impact can’t be understated, believed that humans should observe and learn from animals in order to evolve ourselves. For Beuys, hares and stags in particular were possessed of a deep, communicative energy that was unlocked or evoked via performance or installation.

A prime example is Lightning with Stag in its Glare (1958–85), a pivotal piece in the Tate Modern’s collection. Rough objects stand in for living creatures, while a heavy mass of bronze represents the titular flash of lighting that shines upon the stag. Strewn across the floor are lumpy metal forms that represent the numb, apathetic modern masses who refuse to evolve—what Nietzsche would have termed “the last man.”

Like Beuys, Gabriel Rico achieves a mysterious and weighty magic, using inanimate objects to awaken the spirit of the animal world. Exploring this bestiary is a revelation. In one piece, I witnessed a bolt of lightning race through a branch, becoming a vein connecting branch and rock. Elsewhere, a cat leaps toward a triangular, neon lightning bolt. It emerges from the hoof and folds into a rectangle; it forms a full moon with the branches, while the deer crouches down, and stares.

Why this continued and cyclical obsession with animals among artists? In the wake of modernism, animals were “rediscovered” as symbols of renewal, of alternative possibilities and potentials. They became physics, canny disrupters who could shatter the systems of modernity itself. Nature’s self-sufficiency, her ability to sacrifice and restore, looked tempting in the face of industrial production and an endless array of cheap and disposable consumer goods.

Like Beuys, Gabriel Rico is a storyteller who concocts profound bestiaries. But while the late German artist preferred a rather cold and hermetic style, Rico’s visual fables let the outside world in: an embrace of toy-like colors and images, a sense of humor and childish delight.

In the end, though, this humor brings with it a touch of melancholy. Despite the bright hues and playful forms, Rico’s work, to me, presents an elegy for modernity. There’s a sense of apprehension toward the very future of our biosphere, a knowledge that this entire Anthropocene age (and its art, and its animals) will eventually become mere archaeological objects.

November 2022
Qiu Zhijie
descriptionESP:
El título de la exposición individual de Gabriel Rico en el Sea World Culture and Arts Center - “An Animal I Am!”- es sencillo, pero escurridizo. “Soy un animal”, dice el artista, haciéndose eco de la llamada de lo salvaje; “¡un animal soy!”, aúlla, desatando un despertar aún más profundo y personal

¿Cómo debemos interpretar los animales que pueblan la obra del artista mexicano, en forma de taxidermia real o de formas escultóricas? Desde luego, son algo más que bestias mudas del campo o del bosque. En la terapia con arena -un tipo de “juego” terapéutico cuya invención se remonta a los años veinte-, las figuras de animales son símbolos significativos y potentes. Los animales también desempeñan un papel central en otros rincones espirituales, desde los tótems tribales hasta las tradiciones chamánicas.

La psicología junguiana se centra en despertar los arquetipos que existen en las profundidades del subconsciente humano colectivo. En esta modalidad, los animales son los comunicadores indispensables de todo el ciclo vital, héroes culturales que robaron el fuego y las semillas a Dios. Son profetas, guardianes de secretos, tanto la ofrenda sacrificial como el que sacrifica.

Por supuesto, el hilo bestial en el arte contemporáneo es profundo. Consideremos la épica obra escultórica del difunto Huang Yongping, que incorporaba enormes formas animales -elefantes, pulpos- utilizando materiales tanto orgánicos como artificiales.

Joseph Beuys, cuyo impacto no puede subestimarse, creía que los humanos debíamos observar a los animales y aprender de ellos para evolucionar. Para Beuys, las liebres y los ciervos en particular poseían una energía profunda y comunicativa que se desvelaba o evocaba a través de la performance o la instalación.

Un ejemplo excelente es Lightning with Stag in its Glare (1958-85), una pieza fundamental de la colección de la Tate Modern. Objetos toscos sustituyen a criaturas vivas, mientras que una pesada masa de bronce representa el relámpago que brilla sobre el ciervo. Esparcidas por el suelo hay formas metálicas abultadas que representan a las masas modernas insensibles y apáticas que se niegan a evolucionar, lo que Nietzsche habría denominado “el último hombre“.

Al igual que Beuys, Gabriel Rico logra una magia misteriosa y de peso, utilizando objetos inanimados para despertar el espíritu del mundo animal. Explorar este bestiario es una revelación. En una obra, soy testigo de cómo un rayo atraviesa una rama, convirtiéndose en una vena que conecta rama y roca. En otro lugar, un gato salta hacia un rayo triangular de neón. Sale de la pezuña y se pliega en un rectángulo; forma una luna llena con las ramas, mientras el ciervo se agacha y se queda mirando.

¿Por qué esta obsesión continua y cíclica de los artistas por los animales? Tras el modernismo, los animales fueron “redescubiertos“ como símbolos de renovación, de posibilidades y potenciales alternativos. Se convirtieron en físicos, en astutos perturbadores capaces de hacer añicos los sistemas de la propia modernidad. La autosuficiencia de la naturaleza, su capacidad de sacrificio y restauración, resultaban tentadoras frente a la producción industrial y a un sinfín de bienes de consumo baratos y desechables.

Al igual que Beuys, Gabriel Rico es un narrador que urde profundos bestiarios. Pero mientras que el difunto artista alemán prefería un estilo más bien frío y hermético, las fábulas visuales de Rico dejan entrar el mundo exterior: un abrazo de colores e imágenes de juguete, sentido del humor y deleite infantil.

Al final, sin embargo, este humor trae consigo un toque de melancolía. A pesar de los tonos brillantes y las formas juguetonas, la obra de Rico me parece una elegía de la modernidad. Hay una sensación de aprensión hacia el futuro mismo de nuestra biosfera, un conocimiento de que toda esta era del Antropoceno (y su arte, y sus animales) acabará convirtiéndose en meros objetos arqueológicos.

Noviembre de 2022
Qiu Zhijie
